snippet: Sanctions aimed at the Syrian government have cut its financial reserves in half, and pressure must be maintained on Damascus to stop its bloody crackdown, France’s foreign minister said.
abstract: French Foreign Min Alain Juppe announces at a meeting of 57 countries that have imposed sanctions against Syria that those sanctions must continue, despite a shaky five-day cease fire, in order to force a true end to the bloody crackdown on opposition forces; sanctions have cut Syria's financial reserves in half, damaging its ability to finance and arm militias.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Neil MacFarquhar and Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon; Glenn Kates from Moscow; and J. David Goodman and Rick Gladstone from New York.

lead_paragraph: Sanctions aimed at the Syrian government have cut its financial reserves in half, and pressure must be maintained on Damascus to stop its bloody crackdown, France’s foreign minister said.

headline.seo: Syrian Regime Bleeds Cash as Cease-Fire Is Threatened
headline.main: Push in Paris for More Pressure on Syria as Money Ebbs and Cease-Fire Wobbles
headline.print_headline: Push in Paris for More Pressure on Syria As Money Ebbs and Cease-Fire Wobbles
